,Neuroaxonal dystrophy is a type of cerebral degeneration that affects the axons, or nerve fibers, in the brain. It primarily involves the loss of myelin, which is a fatty substance that insulates and protects the axons. This can lead to a breakdown in communication between neurons and result in symptoms such as cognitive decline, movement problems, and sensory loss.",2,True

,Gangliosidosis is a type of autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by the accumulation of lipids known as gangliosides. It is considered to be a sphingolipidosis, which is a group of genetic disorders that are caused by the improper breakdown of sphingolipids. These disorders can lead to the accumulation of abnormal amounts of sphingolipids in various tissues of the body, including the nervous system, where they can cause damage and death of neurons. Gangliosidosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, which means that a person must inherit two copies of the gene for the disease to develop.",4,True

,Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, including the brain and spinal cord. It is characterized by inflammation and demyelination of the nerve fibers, leading to a progressive loss of function and disability. There are different types of MS, which can be classified based on the areas of the central nervous system that are affected and the severity of the disease. The most common type is relapsing-remitting MS, which involves recurring episodes of symptoms followed by periods of remission. Other types include primary progressive MS, secondary progressive MS, and clinically isolated syndrome (CIS), which is a single episode of neurological symptoms that may indicate the onset of MS. Treatment options for MS typically involve medications to reduce inflammation and slow the progression of the disease, as well as physical and occupational therapy to help manage symptoms and improve function.",7,True

:has_definition ""A multiple sclerosis that is characterized by relapse (attacks of symptom flare-ups) followed by remission (periods of recovery). Symptoms may vary from mild to severe, and relapses and remissions may last for days or months. More than 80 percent of people who have MS begin with relapsing-remitting cycles.""

,Relapsing-Remitting Multiple Sclerosis (RRMS) is a type of multiple sclerosis characterized by relapse and remission phases. During the relapsing phase, symptoms worsen as the disease responds to an attack, followed by periods of recovery or remission. The severity of symptoms can range from mild to severe, and the duration of relapses and remissions may last for days, weeks, months, or even years. RRMS is the most common type of multiple sclerosis, affecting more than 80% of individuals diagnosed with MS.",4,True

,Pupil disease, also known as Pupillary disorder, is a type of eye disease that affects the pupils. The pupils are the small openings in the center of the eyes that allow light to enter and help regulate vision. Pupil disease can cause a variety of symptoms, including pain, redness, swelling, and blurred vision. In some cases, it can also affect the ability to see colors clearly. Treatment for pupil disease typically involves medications or surgery, depending on the severity of the condition. It is important to consult an eye doctor if you experience any symptoms of pupil disease.",3,True
:has_definition ""A brain disease that is characterized by hyperbilirubinemia-induced brain dysfunction.""

,Kernicterus is a type of brain disease that occurs when there is an excessive build-up of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin is a yellowish pigment found in the breakdown of red blood cells. When bilirubin levels become too high, it can cause damage to the brain and other organs.

Kernicterus can be caused by various factors such as genetic disorders, infections, or reactions to certain medications. It is important for doctors to monitor and treat hyperbilirubinemia (high bilirubin levels) in newborns to prevent kernicterus from developing.

Symptoms of kernicterus can include jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), lethargy, seizures, and even coma. Treatment options may include phototherapy (exposure to blue light), exchange transfusion (blood exchange with another infant), or other supportive measures depending on the severity of the condition.
It is important for individuals who suspect they have kernicterus or are concerned about high bilirubin levels in their newborn to consult a healthcare professional immediately.",3,True
:has_definition ""A pigmentation disease characterized by a high level of bilirubin in the blood, causing a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant.""

,Neonatal jaundice is a condition that occurs in newborn infants, characterized by an excessive amount of bilirubin in their blood. This can cause the skin and other tissues to appear yellowish or orange in color. The condition is often treatable with phototherapy, which involves exposing the baby to special blue light that helps to break down the excess bilirubin in the blood. It's important to note that while neonatal jaundice can be treated and managed, it can also be a sign of more serious underlying conditions, so it's crucial for newborns to receive proper medical care.",4,True

,Glandular cystitis is a type of chronic cystitis that is caused by inflammation or infection of the glands located in the bladder wall. It is also sometimes referred to as interstitial cystitis, which is a broader category that includes other types of chronic cystitis such as cystitis with Hunner's lesions and cystitis associated with autoimmune diseases. The exact cause of glandular cystitis is not well understood, but it is thought to be related to a dysfunction in the communication between the nerves that control the bladder and the muscles that control the bladder's contractions. Symptoms may include pain, pressure, or discomfort in the lower abdomen or pelvic area, urinary frequency, and urgency. Treatment options may include medications to reduce inflammation or pain, dietary changes to avoid foods that irritate the bladder, and behavioral therapies such as bladder training or relaxation techniques. It's important to consult a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment of glandular cystitis.",2,True

It is also referred to as malignant ovarian tumor, malignant tumor of the ovary, ovarian neoplasm, and primary ovarian cancer. The exact cause of ovarian cancer is not yet fully understood, but it can be linked to genetic factors, hormonal imbalances, and certain lifestyle choices such as smoking and obesity. Symptoms may include abdominal pain or bloating, fatigue, loss of appetite, and weight loss. It is important for women to have regular check-ups with their healthcare provider to detect any potential issues early on.",10,True

,Skin granular cell tumor is a type of skin benign neoplasm, also known as granular cell neoplasm of the skin or granular cell tumor of skin. It is a non-cancerous growth that occurs when granular cells within the skin multiply and grow in an uncontrolled manner. These cells are typically found near sweat glands, hair follicles, or sebaceous glands.

Granular cell tumors can be flesh-colored, pink, red, or even have a blueish tinge. They are usually small and firm to the touch, with a smooth surface. They may appear as one large mass, or multiple smaller growths.

It is important to note that while granular cell tumors are typically benign and not cancerous, they can sometimes be mistaken for skin cancer due to their appearance. Therefore, it is essential to have any suspicious-looking skin growths evaluated by a dermatologist to ensure they are what they seem.",5,True

The glomus body is a network of blood vessels found in various organs, including the kidney, liver, stomach, and intestines. Glomus tumors are typically slow-growing and benign, but they can cause symptoms if they become large enough to press on nearby structures or if they bleed heavily. Treatment options for glomus tumors include surgery, embolization (a procedure that blocks the blood flow to the tumor), and radiation therapy.",4,True

Blepharoconjunctivitis can be treated with antibiotics, artificial tears, and other medications to help reduce inflammation and promote healing. ,Congenital nervous system abnormality is a type of physical disorder that refers to a non-progressive alteration in the structure of the nervous system present at birth. It is often caused by genetic or environmental factors, and can result in a wide range of symptoms depending on the location and severity of the anomaly.

One possible way to classify congenital nervous system abnormalities is into two main categories: structural abnormalities and functional abnormalities. Structural abnormalities involve changes in the actual structure of the nervous system, such as anatomical defects or malformations, while functional abnormalities refer to problems with the way the nervous system functions, such as neurological disorders.

Examples of congenital nervous system abnormalities include hydrocephalus, spina bifida, cerebral palsy, and epilepsy. These conditions can affect various aspects of a person's life, including their physical abilities, cognitive functioning, and emotional well-being. Treatment options for congenital nervous system abnormalities vary depending on the specific condition and its severity, but may include surgery, medication, physical therapy, or other forms of intervention.",4,True
:has_definition ""A neuropathy that involves damage to nerves of the peripheral nervous system.""

It is characterized by a range of symptoms including numbness, tingling, and pain in the hands, feet, and fingers. This condition can be caused by a variety of factors such as diabetes, autoimmune disorders, and physical trauma. It is important to consult with a medical professional if you suspect you may have peripheral sensory neuropathy.",4,True

,Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) is a condition where the small blood vessels in the stomach become narrowed or blocked, leading to reduced blood flow and potential problems with digestion. It can be caused by factors such as obesity, high blood pressure, diabetes, and smoking. The condition is often diagnosed through endoscopy, which allows doctors to view the inside of the stomach and upper part of the small intestine. Treatment options for GAVE may include lifestyle changes, medication, or surgery depending on the severity of the condition and other health factors. It is important to follow your doctor's recommendations for treatment and management of this condition to prevent complications such as gastritis, ulcers, or even cancer.",2,True

,Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a type of skin cancer that starts in the basal cells, which are located at the base of the epidermis. It's also referred to as epithelioma basal cell or rodent ulcer. BCC can occur anywhere on the body but is most common on areas exposed to sunlight, such as the face, neck, and shoulders.

There are several subtypes of BCC, including superficial, nodular, and morpheaform. Each subtype has unique characteristics in terms of appearance and behavior. Superficial BCC appears as a flat, scaly patch that may become crusted or scabbed over. Nodular BCC resembles a pearly white or skin-colored dome, while morpheaform BCC presents as a scar-like area with pink or red coloring.

BCC is generally considered to be less aggressive than other types of skin cancer, such as melanoma. However, if left untreated, it can grow larger and invade surrounding tissues, leading to disfigurement or even life-threatening complications. Therefore, it's essential to seek medical attention promptly if you notice any suspicious growths or changes on your skin.

Treatment options for BCC include surgical excision, Mohs surgery, and other techniques like cryotherapy or electrocautery. Prevention measures, such as using broad-spectrum sunscreen, wearing protective clothing, and avoiding prolonged sun exposure, can also help minimize the risk of developing BCC in the future.",11,True

An immune system disease is indeed any disease or condition that affects the immune system, which is responsible for defending our bodies against infections and other harmful substances.

The immune system has various components such as lymph nodes, spleen, bone marrow, thymus, tonsils, adenoids, and white blood cells like T-cells and B-cells. Any disorder or abnormal functioning of these components can lead to an immune system disease. Some common examples include:

1. Autoimmune diseases: These occur when the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy body tissues, resulting in inflammation, swelling, and damage to organs and other body parts. Examples include rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, and multiple sclerosis.

2. Infections: These are caused by the invasion of harmful microorganisms like bacteria, viruses, or fungi. The immune system fights these invaders to prevent illnesses such as pneumonia, herpes, and HIV/AIDS.
3. Allergies: These occur when the immune system reacts abnormally to harmless substances like pollen, pet dander, or food allergens, leading to symptoms such as sneezing, itching, and hives.

4. Immune deficiency disorders: These are conditions where the immune system is weakened or doesn't function properly, making individuals more susceptible to infections and illnesses. Examples include AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome), primary immunodeficiency diseases, and secondary immunodeficiency disorders.

It's important to note that the definition of an immune system disease can vary depending on the context or source providing the information. However, in general, any condition that affects the functioning or components of the immune system is considered an immune system disease.",3,True

,Germ cell cancer, also known as germinal tumor or testicular germ cell cancer, is a type of cancer that occurs in the reproductive organs. It typically affects men between the ages of 25 and 49. This type of cancer begins in the sperm-producing cells (germ cells) within the testicles.

1. Dysgerminoma - a benign tumor that consists mainly of immature germ cells.
2. Germinoma - a malignant tumor made up of mature germ cells.

4. Choriocarcinoma - a malignant tumor that consists mainly of placental tissue, which is an abnormal growth of the placenta from pregnancy.
5. Teratoma - a benign tumor made up of various types of tissue, including germ cells, somatic cells, and other substances such as bone or cartilage.

Germ cell cancer can be treated with surgery, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy, depending on the type and stage of the cancer. These tumors are primarily composed of glial cells, which are responsible for supporting and protecting neurons in the brain. They can be located in various parts of the brain and spine, including the cerebrum, cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord.

Treatment options for high-grade glioma typically involve surgical resection, followed by radiation therapy and chemotherapy. However, even with aggressive treatment, the tumor may continue to grow or spread, leading to further complications and a reduced quality of life.

Treatment for spinal cord disease varies depending on the cause and severity of the injury. ,Central nervous system disease refers to a condition or illness that affects the central nervous system, which includes the brain and spinal cord. This can encompass a wide range of disorders, such as traumatic brain injuries, neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's or Parkinson's, and even infections that can cause inflammation and damage to the central nervous system.

The central nervous system is responsible for various essential functions, including control of movement, sensory perception, and cognition (thought processes). Diseases of this system can lead to a range of symptoms, depending on which specific area or function is affected. For example, a disease affecting the motor areas may cause weakness or paralysis in certain body parts, while diseases affecting the sensory areas might result in altered senses (e.g., vision, hearing).

Diagnosing and treating central nervous system diseases requires specialized knowledge and expertise from healthcare professionals such as neurologists or neurosurgeons. These mood swings can range from periods of mania (heightened energy, racing thoughts, reckless behavior) to depression (feeling sad, hopeless, and tired). Bipolar disorder is characterized by at least one episode of mania or hypomania (a less intense form of mania) and one episode of major depression. It can also be accompanied by symptoms such as impulsive spending, risky sex behavior, and increased activity or energy levels.

,Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system. It is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A, which is responsible for breaking down ganglioside, a type of sugar molecule found in nerve cells. When there isn't enough hexosaminidase A to break down ganglioside, it accumulates and causes damage to the nervous system, leading to symptoms such as developmental delay, blindness, paralysis, and dementia. The disease typically begins in early childhood and results in death within two to three years of onset. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, meaning that both copies of the gene must be mutated for the disorder to develop.",5,True
